results.headline: Review: ‘A Walk in the Woods,’ With Robert Redford, Is a Scenic Trek Spoiled
results.summary_short: Mr. Redford stars with Nick Nolte in this film based on Bill Bryson’s 1998 chronicle of hiking the Appalachian Trail with an old friend.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Walk in the Woods

results.headline: Review: ‘My Voice, My Life,’ a Story of Hong Kong Student Actors
results.summary_short: This documentary from Ruby Yang, about students who are not the expected high achievers, captures the feeling of spreading one’s wings onstage for the first time.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Voice, My Life

results.headline: Review: In ‘Z for Zachariah,’ an End-of-Days Love Triangle
results.summary_short: Margot Robbie stars in Craig Zobel’s post-apocalyptic film about three survivors of the nuclear holocaust caught in a triangle.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Z for Zachariah

results.headline: Review: ‘Zipper’ Stars Patrick Wilson as a Sex Addict
results.summary_short: The film, directed by Mora Stephens, finds a straight-arrow prosecutor with an out-of-control libido.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zipper

results.headline: Review: Korean Warriors Seek Vengeance in ‘Memories of the Sword’
results.summary_short: Park Heung-sik’s martial-arts spectacle is set during the Goreyo era in Korea’s history.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Memories of the Sword

results.headline: Review: ‘I Touched All Your Stuff,’ a Documentary About a Technician’s Story
results.summary_short: An American computer technician serving time in a Brazilian jail recounts his ill-fated obsession with a mysterious femme fatale who may or may not exist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Touched All Your Stuff

results.headline: Review: In ‘When Animals Dream’ a Teenager’s Secret Is a Revelation Even to Her
results.summary_short: This Danish thriller regards its monstrous heroine with empathy rather than horror, and is as much a romantic coming-of-age story as a thriller.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When Animals Dream

results.headline: Review: In ‘Unsullied,’ a Competitive Racer Must Run for Her Life
results.summary_short: Directed by the former N.F.L. defensive end Simeon Rice, this lurid low-budget thriller recalls 1970s exploitation revenge pictures.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unsullied

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Second Mother,’ a Guest Flouts Boundaries
results.summary_short: In Anna Muylaert’s Brazilian drama, the maid’s teenage daughter comes to visit and doesn’t seem to care for a lot of the rules.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Second Mother

results.headline: Review: ‘Fever,’ a French Tale of High School Homicide and Consequences
results.summary_short: Raphael Neal’s drama explores a murder committed by two high school seniors in Paris and their subsequent moral struggles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fever

results.headline: Review: In ‘We Are Your Friends,’ Angelenos Long for Life Beyond the Valley
results.summary_short: Zac Efron plays a D.J. under the wing of a dissolute mentor (Wes Bentley) in Max Joseph’s debut feature.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are Your Friends

results.headline: Review: ‘7 Chinese Brothers,’ a Slacker Comedy Starring Jason Schwartzman and His Dog
results.summary_short: This droll film, written and directed by Bob Byington, drifts aimlessly but appealingly with Mr. Schwartzman as its lost hero.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 7 Chinese Brothers

results.headline: Review: Elisabeth Moss at All Angles in ‘Queen of Earth’
results.summary_short: Alex Ross Perry’s narrative experiment, starring Katherine Waterston and Ms. Moss, turns out to be an art house film in quotation marks.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Queen of Earth

results.headline: Review: ‘No Escape,’ Starring Owen Wilson as a Man in the Cross Hairs
results.summary_short: An American businessman and his family are trapped in the middle of a gruesome uprising in a Southeast Asian country.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Escape

results.headline: Review: ‘The Iron Ministry’ Uses Train Passengers to Tell China’s Story
results.summary_short: J. P. Sniadecki spent nearly three years filming this documentary on the trains that carry tens of millions across the nation each year.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Iron Ministry

results.headline: Review: ‘Learning to Drive’ Charts a Culture-Bridging Friendship
results.summary_short: This grown-up drama stars Patricia Clarkson as a New York book critic, and Ben Kingsley as her Indian-American driving instructor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Learning to Drive

results.headline: Review: In ‘Youth,’ Strains of Family and Country Fall on Brothers’ Shoulders
results.summary_short: Crude fantasy seems to merge with the daily reality of a militarized society as brothers try to save their family from financial ruin in this Tom Shoval film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Youth

results.headline: Review: In ‘Guidance,’ a High School Counselor as a Rotten Role Model
results.summary_short: Pat Mills wrote, directed and stars in this black comedy about a former child star who fraudulently gets a job of giving advice to teenagers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Guidance

results.display_title: Searching For Home: Coming Back From War
results.headline: ‘Searching for Home,’ a Cross-Generational Look at Military Veterans
results.summary_short: Eric Christiansen’s documentary explores the struggles of veterans who returned home from World War II and succeeding conflicts, from the wars in Korea and Vietnam to those in Iraq and Afghanistan.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Searching For Home: Coming Back From War

results.headline: Review: ‘Some Kind of Beautiful’ Stars Pierce Brosnan as a Serial Seducer
results.summary_short: Mr. Brosnan plays a womanizing college professor who impregnates a student (Jessica Alba) and then connects with her sister (Salma Hayek) after she dumps him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Some Kind Of Beautiful
